revision.text: ==English== ===Etymology 1=== Imitative. ====Verb==== {{en-verb}} # {{lb|en|intransitive|archaic}} To [[growl]] or [[snarl]] like a [[dog]]. #* '''1921''', ''Chamber's Journal'' #*: She yapped and '''yarred''' and ran in foolish circles, as though quarrelling with her own tail. #* '''1653''', {{w|Fran√ßois Rabelais}}, {{w|Thomas Urquhart}} (translator), ''{{w|Gargantua and Pantagruel}}'' #*: And when he saw that all the dogs were flocking about her, '''yarring''' at the retardment of their access to her, and every way keeping such a coil with her as they are wont to do about a proud or salt bitch, he forthwith departed {{...}} ===Etymology 2=== ====Noun==== {{en-noun|-}} # {{lb|en|UK|dialect}} The plant {{taxlink|Spergula arvensis|species}}, the [[corn spurry]]. ===Etymology 3=== ====Pronunciation==== * {{audio|en|LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-yarr.wav|Audio (UK)}} ====Interjection==== {{en-interj}} # {{alt form|en|arr||used stereotypically in imitation of pirates}} #: '''''Yarr''', this be a fine ship.'' ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=arry|'Arry}} [[Category:en:Animal sounds]] [[Category:en:Carnation family plants]]
